awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a laser confocal microscope to enhance faculty research and undergraduate research training
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Saint Mary’s College of California, a Hispanic-serving Institution, for the acquisition of a laser confocal microscope to be used for research and research training of a diverse population of undergraduates. The acquisition of this microscope will allow faculty to train the next generation of scientists in the use of this imaging technology through academic course work and course-based research experiences in both introductory Biology courses and upper division courses in Cell Biology, Developmental Biology and Microbiology courses. This instrument will also help advance research programs of faculty who normally mentor multiple undergraduate students, thereby providing valuable research, publication and presentation opportunities for students and helping them to prepare the students for graduate programs and careers in STEM. In addition, this instrument will be incorporated into microscopy workshops for middle school students and community outreach to nearby high-need high schools and local community colleges.

The confocal microscope will impact a broad range of research projects including dendritic growth regulation in sympathetic neurons; the cellular interactions in predatory bacteria; the function of various polymorphisms in endogenous retroviruses; the role of Rho-GTPases and signaling pathways in the establishment and maintenance of adherens junctions; the role of histone methyltransferases in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii; the genetic links between gamete and embryo development; effects of environmental toxins on embryo and germ cell development; factors affecting reproductive lifespan; and identifying unculturable microorganisms present on skin and environmental surfaces. In addition, this microscope will allow the faculty to pursue novel avenues of research that were previously difficult to pursue at Saint Mary’s College. Furthermore, the availability of this instrument will allow faculty and student researchers to address impactful research questions, bring their research to fruition sooner and disseminate their work to the scientific community through conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Major Research Instrumentation grant supported the acquisition of the first laser confocal microscope at Saint Mary’s College. The main goals of acquiring this microscope were to enhance faculty research capabilities within the School of Science, further improve undergraduate research and training and expose students and teachers from K-12 schools to confocal microscopy. The instrument was installed in December 2021. Over the past three years, 8 of 13 full time faculty members in the Biology department have been trained on the instrument  - 5 of the 8 have used the instrument for their research and for research training of undergraduate students, others have provided demonstration of the microscope for their classes or are planning to use the microscope for their research. In addition, three adjunct faculty members in the Biotechnology Master’s program have incorporated projects in the graduate Cell Biology course that require the use of this equipment. Examples of research projects include examination of dendritic growth regulation in sympathetic neurons, evaluating the effects of toxic compounds such as BPA and microplastics on embryonic development and cellular health, exploring the mechanisms underlying metastasis in breast cancer cells, and studying the genetic mechanisms underlying cellular differentiation of human placental cells. These projects have resulted in one peer-reviewed publication, two manuscripts in preparation and multiple presentations at regional and national conferences, all of which involved undergraduate students as co-authors or presenters. In addition, training and use of this confocal microscope has been incorporated into Biology laboratory courses such as upper division cell biology course for undergraduates and Advanced Research Methods courses for graduate Biotechnology students. In addition, the Saint Mary’s faculty have incorporated this microscope as a station within a microscopy workshop created for middle school students, and it was also used by one high school student for his science fair project. Around 75 middle school students across the region attended these workshops over the past 2 years and were exposed to confocal microscopy as a result of this award.
